description: From Middle English derkenen, dirkenen, from Old English *deorcnian, *diercnian (“to darken”), from Proto-West Germanic *dirkinōn (“to darken”), equivalent to dark +‎ -en.
Cognate with Scots derken, durken (“to darken”), Old High German tarchanjan, terchinen (“to darken”), Middle High German terken, derken (“to darken”).

verbs.description: darken (third-person singular simple present darkens, present participle darkening, simple past and past participle darkened)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make dark or darker by reducing light.
(intransitive) To become dark or darker (having less light).
(impersonal) To get dark (referring to the sky, either in the evening or as a result of cloud).
examples: He looked up. It was darkening here as well. Sky getting red, the edge of the quarry dark and jagged against it.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make dark or darker in colour.
examples: She puts on lipstick and darkens her eyebrows, which are now very scanty  […]

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become dark or darker in colour.
examples: The lovely hair had lost its rose-gold glimmer, and had darkened to rose-brown  […]

entries.meaning: (transitive) To render gloomy, darker in mood.
examples: It was a pleasure seeing you again. I’m only sorry I had to darken the pleasure with my private problems.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become gloomy, darker in mood.
examples: His countenance darkened while he spoke  […]
When your letter came to me, I was so darkened by an inflammation in my eye, that I could not for some time read it.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be blinded, lose one’s eyesight.
(transitive) To cloud, obscure, or perplex; to render less clear or intelligible.
(transitive) To make foul; to sully; to tarnish.
